alert.note: Alert for Aurora; Bon Homme; Davison; Douglas; Hanson; Hutchinson; Jerauld; Sanborn; Yankton (South Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Sioux Falls (Southeastern SD, Southwestern MN, and Northwestern IA)
info.headline: Extreme Fire Danger issued April 19 at 3:06AM MDT by NWS Sioux Falls
info.description: .DISCUSSION... Issued at 401 AM CDT Tue Apr 19 2022 Breezy and dry southeasterly flow will again lead to very high to extreme fire danger concerns for today. Winds will quickly be strengthening during the morning hours, with sustained winds 25 to 30 mph and gusts up to 50 mph, largely for areas west of the I-29 corridor. Could see a round of flurries/sprinkles move from west to east during the morning hours, though without any measurable amounts expected, these will bring no relief to the already dry antecedent conditions. Drier air will be brought into the region during the morning hours, with relative humidity values in the 20 to 30 percent range expected. Thus, very high to critical fire weather conditions are expected for areas west of I-29. For locations east of I-29, high fire danger is expected due to breezy winds up to 35 mph and RH`s in the 30s to 40s. For Wednesday, looking at scattered showers and thunderstorms moving through the area from west to east throughout the day. Areas west of I-29 will likely receive the least amount of rainfall, expecting 0.1 to 0.25 inches, so will need to monitor how quickly those fuels can dry out after the rain moves out as breezy conditions are again expected for the rest of the day. For locations east of I-29, 0.25 to 0.5 inches of rain are looking possible, thus keeping the fire danger threat on the lower end. People are urged to exercise extreme care with respect to outdoor activities that could cause grass fires. Avoid equipment that can cause sparks near dry grass or brush. Do not toss cigarettes on the ground. Report new fires quickly to the nearest fire department or law enforcement office. ...EXTREME FIRE DANGER... The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the extreme category this afternoon. Extreme weather conditions and very low moisture content of grasses, and other dry organic material on the ground, indicate that critical burning conditions exist. All fires have the potential to become large and spread quickly, becoming erratic with extreme behavioral characteristics. No outdoor burning should take place. OUTLOOK FOR WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON...The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the high category. The grassland fire danger product reflects fire danger for native grasses. It is not intended for cured agricultural crops, nor will it reflect conditions in road ditches which have been mowed.
